prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell a buddy that no one wants his girlfriend to come to game night?
My group of friends have a once a month game night.  It’s mostly just the five of us getting drunk, playing cards or board games, and catching up.   It’s probably sad, but it used to be the highlight of my month.  

One of my friends has a girlfriend who for the last four times has tagged along.  None of us minded when he first asked if she could come, but she’s made these get together completely un enjoyable.  

She’s nice enough I guess, but she’s insanely annoying.   She always has to be the center of attention.  She talks about herself and her opinion almost nonstop and she’s really not that interesting so it doesn’t make for good conversation.  If someone is talking, she will interrupt and find a way to bring it back to her.  If the person keeps talking she will just talk over them.  I’ve sat there and watched her do it and raise her voice on purpose just to be louder than the person talking.  

Another thing that’s been awkward for me personally is that she tries to make me a stereotype.  I’m gay.  I’m not the “gay bff” type of guy though.  Yet she keeps trying to make me into hers.  She’s always getting weirdly touchy feely with me.  She tries to have “girl talk” with me.  One time she learned that I was going out to a gay bar and shows up uninvited and basically followed me around and ruined my entire night.   I’ve tried to be tactful with her since she’s my buddy’s girl, but she does not get the hint.  One time I went so far as to tell her that I don’t have any female friends because I just really only get along with guys (lie), but in one ear and out the other.  

No one except her boyfriend wants her there.   The rest of us have all talked about it.  None of us like her.   We just don’t know how to tell him.  I’m a rip the bandaid off kind of guy and just want to take him out for a beer and tell him.  I would be nice about it.  I already know the gist of what I would say.  “The group dynamic has just changed with a girl in the mix.  We’d like to make it a guys only night and maybe get together with you guys as a couple a different night. “.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a group of friends who don't want his friend's girlfriend to come to their game nights. They've tried being tactful, but she keeps being annoying and making them uncomfortable, especially with her behavior towards the author who is gay.

First, I need to consider the rights and wrongs here. The author is part of a group that's been having monthly game nights. The girlfriend has been coming for the last four times, but her behavior is making the group uncomfortable. They've talked about it among themselves and want to tell her boyfriend that they don't want her there anymore. The author is suggesting a direct approach, being nice but clear.

On one hand, the group has a right to their social space and should be able to set boundaries. If the girlfriend is making the group uncomfortable, they have a reason to want her not to attend. The author is trying to protect the group's enjoyment and their own comfort, especially with the unwanted attention and stereotypes the author is facing.

On the other hand, the author is considering confronting the boyfriend directly. The method of communication is important here. The author mentions being nice and clear, which is a responsible approach. But is it wrong to exclude someone from a social event, even if they're not part of the original group? The girlfriend isn't part of the original five friends, so maybe it's reasonable to ask her not to come. However, the way they phrase it could matter. Suggesting a "guys only" night might come off as excluding the boyfriend's partner, which could be seen as targeting her, but if the group is primarily male and the dynamic changes with her presence, maybe it's a necessary adjustment.

Also, the author's personal issues with the girlfriend are valid. The unwanted behavior and making the author uncomfortable is a legitimate reason. The key is whether the author and the group are being respectful in their approach. Since they've discussed it among themselves and want to address it directly with the boyfriend in a polite manner, they're not just being rude. They're trying to maintain their group's comfort and cohesion.

So, considering all this, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong. They have valid reasons for wanting to set boundaries and are approaching the situation carefully. The answer would be B (No).
